benchmark_config.jira_title: Implement/Test API: PUT /1.0/kb/admin/payments/{paymentId}/transactions/{paymentTransactionId} - Update existing paymentTransaction and associated payment state

covered: Valid Request: TC01 (successful update) demonstrates proper update flow.
Non-Existing Resource: TC06 (paymentId) and TC07 (paymentTransactionId) scenarios cover 404 paths.
Missing/Invalid Headers: TC03 (missing X-Killbill-CreatedBy) and TC26 (header variations) address header handling.
Invalid ID Formats: TC04 (invalid paymentId) and TC05 (invalid paymentTransactionId).
Authentication: TC11 covers HTTP 401 Unauthorized when credentials are missing/invalid.
Malformed/Missing Body and JSON: TC09 (missing body) and TC10 (malformed JSON).
State/Data Validation: TC08 (invalid state data), TC14 (max values), TC15 (min/empty values), TC16 (timeout behavior).
Extra/Unsupported Inputs: TC13 (extra fields ignored), TC25 (extra query parameters).
Concurrency and Stability: TC17 (concurrent updates) and TC20 (regression for previously problematic state).
Security: TC18 (SQL injection) and TC19 (XSS) tests.
Performance/Resilience: TC21 (high load), TC22 (dependent service degraded).
Headers/Combinations: TC02 (optional headers), TC24 (combinations of optional headers).
gaps: Authorization: No explicit test for 403 Forbidden due to insufficient privileges (only 401 Unauthorized covered).
Caching Behavior: No tests covering caching headers (ETag, Cache-Control) for PUT operations.
Pagination: Not applicable for PUT, but no dedicated pagination checks are present ( guideline mentions GET-like pagination checks; not strictly needed here ).
Rate Limiting: No explicit tests focusing on rate limiting/throttling for PUT requests.
recommendations: Add a test case for 403 Forbidden to cover insufficient privileges (not just unauthenticated).
Add caching-related checks for PUT responses if relevant (ETag/Cache-Control) even for update operations.
Introduce explicit rate-limiting/throttling scenarios to confirm behavior under bursty traffic (e.g., 429 Too Many Requests).
Consider a focused test for 204 vs 200 behavior when the update results in no actual changes (no-op updates).
Document and test any domain-specific constraints around state transitions to ensure coverage of edge cases not yet explicit (e.g., additional invalid state edge cases).
